CLUE: Apt or witty remark - in France
OUTPUT: ['"The French don\'t need a dictionary, they just speak fluent mime."', '"In France, the best wine is not in the glass but on the tongue!"', '"French: The language that invented \'je ne sais quoi.\'"', '"In France, you can be late for dinner and still be considered punctual."', '"The French have a saying for everything except how to unclog a toilet."', '"Les Fran√ßais sont-ils toujours aussi charmants lorsqu\'il y a des mouchoirs sur les tables?" (Are the French as charming when there are tissues on the table?)', '"The art of French cuisine is knowing how much food you can eat, and still leave room for dessert."', '"In France, the best compliment to a meal isn\'t praise but \'it was good enough.\'"', '"French: The language that gave us \'d√©j√† vu,\' because it feels like everything is already done before you start."', '"The French art of conversation can sometimes lead one into a labyrinth with no exit, until they find the way out by saying \'Je suis perdu.\'" (I am lost.)', '"In France, when someone offers you cheese, it\'s not just an invitation to eat; it\'s an ode to la culture fran√ßaise."', '"The French know that a good meal isn\'t about the quantity but the quality of flavors and conversation."', '"In France, you can be too polite when ordering food because saying \'I want the chicken without bones\' is considered very rude."', '"French: The language that never ran out of ways to say \'bon app√©tit.\'"', '"The French have a unique way of enjoying meals; they savor each bite as if it were their last, making every meal an art form."', '"In France, the phrase \'Je ne sais quoi\' literally translates to \'I don\'t know what,\' but in essence, it means having a certain indescribable charm or quality."', '"When you can\'t find something in French restaurants, they say \'il n\'y a pas dans le menu.\' But when there is something exactly as described, they proclaim \'c\'est ici!\' (It\'s here!)"', '"French: The language that appreciates the beauty of fine dining so much it has its own verb: \'gourmandir,\' which means to devour food."', '"In France, you can be late for a meal and still have them ready to eat by saying \'Je suis en retard mais ma soupe est pr√™te.\' (I\'m late but my soup is ready.)"', '"The French are so dedicated to their pastries that they say there\'s no goodbye, only \'bonne chance √† votre pain au chocolat!\' (Good luck with your chocolate croissant!)"']
